creator: Master of The Hague, KB, 69 B 10
provenance:
Presented in 1676 by Ernest Ignatius Busch, parish priest of Aelten (Gelderland?), to Johannes Constantinus de Richeliis (Johan Constantijn van Rijckel), decanus Borchensis. Prince Karl of Prussia (stamped ex-libris); by descent to his son Friedrich Leopold of Prussia,
his sale in 1931 at Ball & Graupe, Berlin (cat. 27-28 November, lot 406, pl. 27). Purchased in 1939 from antiquarian bookseller Hanns Wolff, The Hague

4 column miniatures (82/145x90/98 mm) with border decoration, 1 pendrawn column miniature (100x90 mm) with border decoration, 28 historiated initials (45/50x50/55 mm) with border decoration; all border decoration in Utrecht style (large acanthus leaves and/or

etc.) and Utrecht style with `eastern' influences (ff. 119r, 119v, 120r, 120v, 121r)

historiated initials

II: penwork initials (ff. 104r, 149r; 127v, 134v, 140r, etc.)
Binding: contemporary brown leather; blind (panel-stamped)
language: I: littera textualis; II: littera hybrida

title: Prayer Book

Binding: contemporary brown leather; blind

provenance: Niculaus ab Goch. N. ab Heck. Known to have been since 1764 in the collection of Stadholder William V at The Hague; transfered in 1798 to the then newly-erected Nationale Bibliotheek (now: Koninklijke Bibliotheek)

Binding: contemporary brown leather; blind and gilt

title: Augustine, La Cité de Dieu (Vol. I). Translation from the Latin by Raoul de Presles
creator: Orosius Master
provenance:
Louis de Luxembourg, connétable de France (d. 1475; signature, erased); by descent to his granddaughter Françoise de Luxembourg and her husband Philip of Cleves (d. 1528; coat of arms with label; emblems, motto; signature); purchased in 1531 from Philip's estate by
Henry III, Count of Nassau (d. 1538); by descent to the Princes of Orange-Nassau, the later Stadholders, at The Hague; carried off in 1795 to Paris by the French and restituted to the Koninklijke Bibliotheek in 1816
description: 1 two-column miniature (180x180 mm); 10 column miniatures (85/75x80/75 mm); decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 1r, 6r, 33v, 76v, 141r, etc.)
Added: 4 illustrations in the margin (coat of arms, emblems, motto)
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt; with coat of arms of Stadholder William V

title: Lambert of St. Omer, Liber Floridus
provenance:
made for Pierre de Goux et de Wedergraete (d. 1471). Philip of Cleves (d. 1528; signature); purchased in 1531 from his estate by Henri III, Count of Nassau (d. 1538); by descent to the Princes of Orange-Nassau, the later Stadholders, at The Hague; carried off in 1795
to Paris by the French and restituted to the Koninklijke Bibliotheek in 1816
description: 98 coloured drawings
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt; with coat of arms of Stadholder William V

title: Vincent of Beauvais, Le Miroir Historial (Vol. IV). Translation from the Latin by Jean de Vignay
creator: Master of the Cité des Dames
provenance:
acquired before 1492 by Philip of Cleves (d. 1528; coat of arms with label; signature); purchased in 1531 from his estate by Henri III, Count of Nassau (d. 1538); by descent to the Princes of Orange-Nassau, the later Stadholders, at The Hague; carried off in 1795 to
Paris by the French and restituted to the KB in 1816
description: 1 two-column miniature (185x200 mm); 19 column miniatures (110/70x90/85 mm); decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 3r, 10r, 15r, 19r, 20r, etc.)
Added: 1 illustration in the margin (coat of arms)
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt; with coat of arms of Stadholder William V
annotation:
Vol. I-III (now: Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, fr. 308-311) were decorated but not illustrated in the early 15th century. Apparently separated from their fourth volume from the beginning, they were illustrated on behalf of a later owner, Louis de Gruuthuse,
in the early 1450s

bibliographicCitation: The Hague 1998, no. 36, colour pl. on p. 34

Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt; with coat of arms of Stadholder William V

Brussels (no. # 54-55) and transferred in 1823 to the KB

Binding: 18th-century green dyed vellum; gilt

bibliographicCitation: Korteweg 2004, p. 215 no. 87, colour figs. II, 150, 165
title: Book of Hours in Latin and French (use of Paris)
creator: Master of Jean Rolin, follower
provenance: Antoine Moriau (1699-1760), procureur du Roi [de France] et de la ville [de Paris]. Purchased in 1909 as part of the collection of bookbindings of Anton W.M. Mensing (1866-1936) of Amsterdam (no. 1)

Binding: 17th-century red leathergilt; with coat of arms and motto of the Discalced Carmelites

title: Prayer Book
creator: Spierinck
provenance: C. Ploos van Amstel (book-plate; 1781). J.I. Doedes (book-plate and signature), his sale in 1898 at Beijers in Utrecht (cat. 4-5 May, p. 124). Purchased in 1909 as part of the collection of A.W.M Mensing (no. 85)
description:
1 historiated initial (55x60 mm) with border decoration and 1 penwork illustration in the margin; 1 historiated penwork initial (26x30 mm); penwork initials with pen-flourishes in North Holland style (`Haarlem L-lines'; ff. 1r, 39r, 56r, 69v, 74r, 82r,
etc.)
Binding: contemporary brown leather; blind (panelstamped; rebacked)
annotation: Utrecht calendar: besides the usual Utrecht entries feasts in red include St. Jeroen, patron saint of Noordwijk (August 17). F. 10r: `spic' and `1498' (signature and date by Spierinck). F. 122r: `onse eerwaerdighe patroenster maria magdalena'

title: Book of Hours
creator: Masters of Hugo Jansz. van Woerden
provenance: Purchased in 1909 as part of the collection of bookbindings of Anton W.M. Mensing (1866-1936) of Amsterdam (no. 7)
description:
6 full-page miniatures (100/115x65/70 mm) with border decoration; 6 illustrations in the margin; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 14r, 45r, 58r, 74v, 91v, etc.); all border decoration in Leyden style (late coarse variety of `Leyden-blue-acanthus'); 1
penwork initial with pen-flourishes in Leyden style (f. 75r)
Binding: contemporary brown leather; blind panel stamped with date `1497'; clasps engraved `1497'
annotation: Utrecht calendar: besides the usual entries feasts in red include St. Jeroen, patron saint of Noordwijk (17 August). Leyden `spikyï script

title: Book of Hours (use unknown)
provenance: Sold in 1776 at the auction of H. Spruit, Utrecht. Purchased in 1909 as part of the collection of bookbindings of Anton W.M. Mensing (1866-1936) of Amsterdam (no. 82)
description: 1 historiated initial (30x43 mm) with border decoration; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 24v, 34r, 38v, 42r, 45v, etc.); penwork initials with pen-flourishes (ff. 14v, 16r, 16v, 17v, 19r, etc.)
Binding: 16th-century brown leather; blind panelstamped (rebacked) of c. 1530
annotation:
Liège(?) calendar: feasts in red include St. Lambert (September 17), St. Denis (October 9), St. Hubert (November 3). Use of Hours of the Virgin: Prime, Cap.: Quando natus, Ant.: Ab initio, None, Cap.: Ecce Maria, Ant.: Sicut cynamonum; Responsories of the Office of
the Dead: Credo quod, Qui Lazarum, Domine quando, Heu mihi, Ne recorderis, Manus tue, Peccantem me, Deus eterne, Libera me ... de morte. Traces of pelgrimsbadges (ff. I, 13)

title: Book of Hours
creator: Gethsemane Master
provenance: J.I. Doedes (book-plate and signature), his sale in 1898 at Beijers in Utrecht (May 4-5, p. 123, lot e). Purchased in 1909 as part of the collection of bookbindings of Anton W.M. Mensing (1866-1936) of Amsterdam (no. 74)
description: Decorated initials with border decoration in North Holland style (`Haarlem-bunches-of-twigs'; ff. 56r, 110r, 132r; 25v, 31r, etc.) and `Haarlem acanthus'; f. 16r)
Added: 4 full-page miniatures (95x60 mm) with border decoration
Binding: 15th-/16th-century brown leather; blind panelstamped (rebacked)
annotation: Utrecht calendar: besides the usual Utrecht entries feasts in red include St. Jeroen (August 17), St. Eligius (December 1). Litany: St. Augustine first among the confessors. Possibly written in the Southern Netherlands (Southern Netherlandish script)

title: Book of Hours (use of Tournai)
provenance: Purchased in 1909 as part of the collection of bookbindings of Anton W.M. Mensing (1866-1936) of Amsterdam (no. 5)
description: 9 full-page miniatures (117/110x74/60 mm); 14 miniatures (96/39x70/42 mm); 2 illustrations in the margin; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 36r, 47r, 73r, 75r, 77r, etc.)
Binding: contemporary brown leather; blind made by Johannes Guilebert
annotation: Missing one or more quires at the beginning, probably containing calendar. Text of None of Hours of the Virgin, with miniature on opening page, lost. Full-page miniature probably lost before f. 36 (Hours of the Virgin, Vespers)

title: Ferial Psalter (use of Utrecht)
provenance:
Assuerus van Swieten (or: a Zibetey; 1596). J.I. Doedes (book-plate and signature); his sale in 1898 at Beijers in Utrecht (cat. 4-5 May, p. 123 no. l). Purchased in 1909 as part of the collection of bookbindings of Anton W.M. Mensing (1866-1936) of Amsterdam (no.
4)
description: Decorated initials with border decoration in Groningen style (`Selwerd'; ff. 17r, 45r, 62v, 77v, 93r, etc.); penwork initials with pen-flourishes in Groningen style (`Selwerd'; ff. 18v, 19r, 19v, 21v, 24r, etc.)
Added: 1 full-page miniature (86x62 mm) with border deocration (probably over woodcut mal)
Binding: contemporary brown leather; blind
annotation: Utrecht calendar: besides the usual Utrecht entries feasts in red include St. Francis (October 4). Office of the Dead: Utrecht maiores and minores

title: Jean Lemaire de Belges, Genealogie de Madame Anne de la Tour, princesse de l'Ecosse
provenance:
made for Anne de la Tour (d. 1524), countess of Auvergne and Boulogne, eldest daughter and heiress of Jehan III, count of Auvergne and her husband (and cousin) John (Jehan) Stewart (Stuart), Duke of Albany, regent of Scotland (1481-1536), son of Alexander Stewart, Duke
of Albany (d. 1485) and Anne de la Tour d'Auvergne (d. 1487). Paul Petau (d. 1614; inscription, his no. E 55); by descent to his son Alexandre Petau (d. 1672), his sale in 1722 at De Hondt, The Hague (cat. 23 Febr. 1722, lot 85). Purchased in 1909 as part of the collection of
bookbindings of Anton W.M. Mensing (1866-1936) of Amsterdam (no. 2)
description: 13 coloured drawings (unframed; 155/68x140/80 mm); 31 miniatures/coloured drawings (coats of arms; unframed); 1 coloured pendrawn initial with pendrawn border decoration (f. 2r); pendrawn initials (ff. 2v, 3r, 4r, 5v, 6r, etc.)
Binding: 17th-century brown leather; gilt; with coat of arms and monogram (ALPET) of Alexandre Petau and motto: Non est mortale quod opto
annotation: F. 2r and 28r: "Vivite felicex/felices. I.A." with a love-knot (= Jehan and Anne)

title: Prayers
provenance: purchased in 1909 as part of the collection of bookbindings of Anton W.M. Mensing (1866-1936) of Amsterdam (no. 257)
description: 1 coloured drawing (unframed; 97x85); 1 penwork initial with pen-flourishes in North Holland style (related to `brother-Meynaert')

title: Book of Hours (use of Rome)
creator: Jean Pichore, follower
provenance:
made for an owner whose emblem (an initial `I' or two ## embracing entwined `I's with a little animal, possibly a genet, chained to them) is very similar of that of Jeanne de France (d. 1482), wife of Jean II, duke of Bourbon and Auvergne (French: genette, pun on the
name Jeanette). Purchased in 1913 at a sale at W.P. van Stockum, The Hague (cat. 17-19 Dec., p. 75 no. 1001)
description: 14 large miniatures (63/57x44/37 mm); 28 miniatures (35/30x31/25 mm); decorated initials throughout
Added (ff. 1v, 206r): 2 full-page miniatures (unframed; coats of arms)
Binding: 16th-century red leather; gilt (c. 1580)
annotation: general calendar: feasts in red include St. Denis (9 October). Coats of arms in the lower margins of ff. 14r, 21r, 43r, 76v, 148r overpainted during the production of the book

title: Christine de Pisan, L'Epistre d'Othea
provenance: possibly made for Jacques d'Armagnac, Duke of Nemours (d. 1477). Probably acquired as part of the Orange-Nassau collection of Dillenburg Castle in Germany, which was transferred to The Hague in 1821
description: 98 miniatures (100/40x90 mm); decorated initials with border decoration
Binding: 20th-century brown leather (1973; blue silk binding as described by Byvanck 1924; now lost)
annotation: 2 leaves with miniatures (containing the Letters 53 and 56) missing before ff. 51 and 53

title: Book of Hours (use of Rome; part only)
creator: Jean Fouquet, follower
provenance: Joseph Désiré Lupus (d. 1822) of Brussels; purchased with his collection in 1819 by King William I of The Netherlands; kept from 1819-1822 at the Musée Lupus in the Palace of Charles de Lorraine at Brussels (no. A 49) and transferred in 1823 to the KB
description:
1 full-page miniature (miniature + margin; 125x90 mm); 1 full-page miniature (miniature + margin including some lines of text; 125x90 mm); 13 miniatures (75x45 mm); 24 illustrations in the margin (calendar); decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 13r, 15r,
17r, 19r, 33v, etc.)
annotation: general calendar. Texts of Matins and Compline of the Hours of the Virgins, both with miniature, missing before f. 33 and after f. 98. Ms. is not misbound as stated by Schaefer 1994

title: Book of Hours
provenance: Families Van Schoten and Van Egmond (c. 1570-1620). Purchased in 1807 as part of the collection of Joost Romswinckel (1745-1824) of Leiden by King Louis Napoleon of The Netherlands and placed in the KB
description: Decorated initials with border decoration in South Holland style (`anecdotical monkeys'; ff. 19r, 68r, 81r, 106r, 143r, etc.); penwork initials with pen-flourishes in South Holland style (`aubergine'; ff. 7r, 50v, 92v, 141v, 155v, etc. )
Added: 1 miniature (size: full-page + margin, unframed; 130x87 mm)
Binding: 16th-/17th-century black leather; blind
annotation: Utrecht calendar: besides the usual Utrecht entries feasts in black include St. Jeroen, patron saint of Noordwijk (August 17, underlined in red)

bibliographicCitation: The Hague 1983, no. 46, fig. on p. 62
title: Diurnal (winter part; Cistercian use)
creator: Maïtre Henri
provenance: Joseph Désiré Lupus (d. 1822) of Brussels; purchased with his collection in 1819 by King William I of The Netherlands; kept from 1819-1822 at the Musée Lupus in the Palace of Charles de Lorraine at Brussels (no. A 11) and transferred in 1823 to the KB
description: Decorated initials with border decoration throughout; penwork initials with pen-flourishes throughout
Added (ff. 17v, 18r): 2 full-page miniatures (30x12 mm)
Binding: 18th(?)-century black velvet
annotation: related in style to Paris, BNF, nouv. acq. fr. 16251

title: Diurnal (Carthusian use)
provenance:
P.A. Bolongaro-Crevenna; his sale in 1790 at D.J. Changuion & P. den Hengst in Amsterdam (26 Apr.; cat. of 1789, pt. 1, p. 74 no. 319), where purchased by Joost Romswinckel (1745-1824) of Leiden; bought in 1807 as part of the Romswinckel collection by King Louis
Napoleon of The Netherlands and placed in the KB
description: 1 historiated initial (29x29 mm) with border decoration; 4 illustrations in the margin; 1 decorated initial with border decoration (f. 70r); decorated initials (ff. 10r, 33v, 47r, 63r, 155v, etc.); penwork initials with pen-flourishes throughout
Binding: 18th-/19th-century green leather; gilt (made c. 1800)
annotation: Carthusian calendar (misplaced between ff. 10 and 23): feasts in red include St. Hugues of Grenoble (April 1), St. Bruno (October 6; added), Hugues of Lincoln (November 17), Commemoratio fratrum ordinis (November 9)

title: Book of Hours
creator: Masters of Zweder van Culemborg, precursor
provenance: Dijewer Arnt van Hoinendochter, Utrecht (15th cent.). Lyessgen van Westreenen (16th cent.). J. Clarenborch. Purchased in 1895 of antiquarian bookseller J. Tregaskis, London (cat. 1895, no. 28)
description: Penwork initials with pen-flourishes (early form of North Holland `thorn-and-stitch' with `bearded man'; ff. 2r, 3r, 4r, 5r, 6r, etc.)

Added: 1 full-page miniature (60x45 mm) with border decoration; 1 historiated initial (40x45 mm) with border decoration; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 1r, 32r, 48v, 55v, 61r, etc.); all decoration in Utrecht style (`multi-coloured-leaves'); decorated
initials with border decoration in Utrecht style (`green-teardrops'; ff. 48v, 55v, 61r, 67r, 73v, etc.)
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt; with initials M.V.D.H.
annotation: Utrecht calendar. Litany: St. Augustine first among the confessors. Leaves, possibly with miniatures, missing before f. 94r (Mass of the Virgin), f. 117r (Suffrages), f. 167r (Penitential Psalms)

title: Book of Hours (use of Utrecht)
creator: Masters of the Delft Grisailles
provenance: Families Van Matenes, Duivenvoorde and Foreest (c. 1480-1590). Purchased in 1809 as no. 131 of the collection of Jacob Visser (1724-1804) of The Hague
description: 17 full-page grisaille-miniatures (85/70x55/45 mm); decorated initiales with border decoration in Delft style (`coloured'; ff. 1r, 15r, 23r, 31v, 35r, etc.)
Added section: 1 full-page miniature (66x38 mm) with border decoration; decorated initials with border decoration in Delft style (`late coloured'; ff. 144r, 146r, 150r, 152r, 153r, etc.)
Added: 1 grisaille-miniature (f. 93v)
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt
annotation: Utrecht calendar. Office of the Dead: Utrecht maiores and minores (with 9th: Libera me ..de morte). Traces of pilgrim badges on ff. V, VI, 13

title: Book of Hours and Prayer Book (Dominican use)
provenance:
Made for a member of the Bylant family. Philippus Warnerus (16th century). Alexander van der Haweycken (1601). Joseph Désiré Lupus (d. 1822) of Brussels; purchased with his collection in 1819 by King William I of The Netherlands; kept from 1819-1822 at the Musée Lupus
in the Palace of Charles de Lorraine at Brussels (no. A 13)
description:
4 full-page miniatures (90x60/55 mm) with border decoration; 4 miniatures (45x58 mm) with decorated initial and border decoration; 1 historiated initial (40x42 mm) with border decoration; 1 illustration in the margin; decorated initials with border decoration; all
border decoration in Southern Netherlandish style (`strewn borders'); decorated initials with penflourishes (ff. 9r, 17r, 23r, 33v, 58r, etc.); penwork initials with pen-flourishes (ff. 13r, 13v, 14v, 15r, 16r, etc.)
Binding: 18th-/19th-century blue leather; gilt (made c. 1800)
annotation:
Dominican calendar with Liège saints: feasts in red include St. Thomas of Aquino (March 7), St. Vincent (April 5), St. Peter martyr (April 30) and his translation (May 7), St. Servatius `episcopus trajectensis' (May 13), Translation of St. Dominic (May 24), St.
Lambert (August 6), St. Hubertus (October 3), St. Leonard (October 6). F. 101v: Pope Julius II (1503-1513) mentioned

bibliographicCitation: The Hague 1980, no. 38, fig., colour pl. VII

title: Book of Hours (`Hours of Simon de Varie'; use of Paris).
Guillaume Alecis (Alexis), Prayer to Mary
creator: Master of Jean Rolin
Master of the Dunois Hours
Jean Fouquet
provenance:
made for Simon de Varie. Divided in three parts by Philippe de Béthune (d. 1649). Vol. I: Samuel van Huls or Hulsius; his sale in 1730 at J. Swart & P. de Hondt, The Hague (cat. 4 Sept., pt. I, p. 339 no. 5199). J.H. van Wassenaer-van Obdam; his sale in 1750 at P. de
Hondt, The Hague (cat. 10 Aug., p. 63 no. 801), where purchased by Stadholder William IV, Prince of Orange-Nassau; by descent to his son Stadholder William V and his grandson King William I of The Netherlands, who ceded it to the KB in 1816. Vol. II: sold in 1882 at A. Firmin-Didot,
Paris (cat. 12-17 June, pt. IV, pp. 22-23 no. 12). Purchased in 1890 from antiquarian bookseller J. Baer & Co., Frankfurt a.M. (200. Lager-Cat. 1887, p. 2 no. 2). Vol. III resurfaced in 1985 in California (see Marrow 1994)
description:
Vol. I (74 G 37): 17 miniatures (55x32 mm); 4 illustrations in the margin; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 1r, 12r, 17v, 25r, 53r, etc.). Vol. II (74 G 37a): 19 miniatures (55x32 mm); 24 illustrations in the margin (calendar); decorated initials with
border decoration (ff. 2r, 3v, 4v, 5v, 6v, etc.)
Added in vol. II (74 G 37a, ff. 1r-v): 1 full-page miniature (miniature + margin: coat of arms; 116x85 mm); 1 full page miniature (90x70 mm)
annotation: Paris calendar: feasts in red include St. Geneviève (3 January). Vol. III now: Los Angeles, J. Paul Getty Museum, Ms. 7

bibliographicCitation: Dickman Orth 1980, pp. 70, 73 nt. 20, 78, 81, 84, 86-87 (mistakenly as "74 G 48")

title: Book of Hours (`Hours of Jean Lallemant le Jeune'; use of Bourges)
provenance:
made for Jean Lallemant le Jeune, Lord of Marmagne (d. 1548). Purchased in 1750 from J.H. van Wassenaer-van Obdam (his sale at P. de Hondt, The Hague; cat. Aug. 10, p. 63, no. 802) by stadholder William IV, prince of Orange-Nassau; by descent to William I, king of The
Netherlands, who ceded it in 1816 to the KB
description: 12 full-page miniatures (110x65 mm); 1 full-page miniature (coat of arms; 115x65 mm); 24 illustrations in the margin; decorated initials throughout
Binding: 18th-century red leather; gilt made by C. Micke (1768)
annotation: Bourges calendar: feasts in red include St. William, archbishop of Bourges (January 10), St. Sulpice (February 17), St. Austregisillus (May 20), St. Ursinus (December 29)

title: Book of Hours (`Hours of Catharine de Medici'; use of Rome)
provenance:
made c. 1560 for Catherine de Medici after the death of King Henry II of France (d. 1558); by descent to her son King Charles IX of France (inscription). Purchased in 1750 at the sale of J.H. van Wassenaer-van Obdam at P. de Hondt, The Hague (cat. 10 August, p. 63 no.
800) by Jean Royer, pastor of the Église Wallone at The Hague and offered to Stadholder William IV, Prince of Orange-Nassau; by descent to his son Stadholder William V and his grandson King William I of The Netherlands, who ceded it to the KB in 1816
description: 8 full-page miniatures (75x50 mm); 1 full-page miniature (coat of arms; 75x45 mm); decorated initials (ff. 40r, 40v, 41v, 42v, 44r, etc.)
Binding: contemporary red leather; gilt; with the interlaced initials "H" and "C" of Catherine de Medici and Henri II the King of France

title: Book of Hours in Dutch
provenance: Purchased in 1910 from D. Lubach-Numan
description: 2 historiated initials (39/30x40 mm) with border decoration; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 51r, 71r, 99v); penwork initials with pen-flourishes in South Holland style (`aubergine'; ff. 10r, 24v, 31v, 36r, 37v, etc.)
Binding: 17th-/18th-century vellum
annotation: Utrecht calendar: besides the usual Utrecht entries feasts in red include St. Jeroen, patron saint of Noordwijk, (17 August) and St. Augustine (28 August). Litany: St. Augustine first among the confessors

title: Book of Hours
creator: Masters of the Haarlem Bible
provenance: Family notes by Willem Janssen Pauwe (1609-1614) and one of his children (1659). Purchased in 1912 from antiquarian bookseller J. Tregaskis, London
description:
5 miniatures (96/89x69/64 mm) with border decoration, 1 historiated initial (67x70 mm) with border decoration, 1 illustration in the margin; decorated initals with border decoration (ff. 47r, 69r, 115r, 140r, 155r, etc.); all border decroation in North Holland style
(`bunches-of-twigs'); penwork initials with pen-flourishes in North Holland style (`fountains') on most pages
Binding: 17th-/18th-century vellum; blind
annotation:
Utrecht calendar: besides the usual Utrecht entries feasts in red include St. Jeroen, patron saint of Noordwijk, (August 17). Full-page miniature and decorated opening page missing before f. 91 (Hours of the Holy Spirit) and full-page miniature missing before f. 155
(Office of the Dead). f. 177r: Suffrage to St. Bavo. Several quires misbound at end

title: Book of Hours in Dutch
provenance: Agatha Geversd. (16th century). Purchased in 1809 as no. 116 of the collection of Jacob Visser (1724-1804) of The Hague
description: Penwork initials with pen-flourishes in Utrecht style (`crown-and-dragon' with South-Holland elements; ff. 12r, 52r, 68r, 90r, 119r, etc.)
Added: 1 full-page miniature (104x71 mm)
Binding: 17th-century vellum
annotation: Utrecht calendar: besides the usual entries feasts in red include St. Jeroen, patron saint of Noordwijk, (17 August)

title: Fasciculus temporum
provenance:
Johannes, presbyter at Delft (15th century). Paulus van Bemmel (18th century). P. Bondam; his sale in 1800 at B. Wild & J. Altheer, Utrecht (cat. 1 Oct., no. 77), where purchased by Joost Romswinckel (1745-1824) of Leiden; bought in 1807 as part of the Romswinckel
collection by King Louis Napoleon of The Netherlands and placed in the KB
description: 1 coloured drawing (unframed; 97x41 mm)
Binding: contemporary limb vellum wrapper

title: Genealogy of the Kings of England.
Added: Introduction to heraldry.
Roll of arms of European kings and princes.
Chronicle of the Kings of England from William the Conqueror to Henry IV (in Latin)
provenance:
Oud-Bisschoppelijke Clerezij, Utrecht; transfered in 1887 to the Rijksarchief, Utrecht and in 1888 to the Algemeen Rijksarchief, The Hague (now: Nationaal Archief); presented in 1948 to the Koninklijke Bibliotheek on the occasion of its onehundred-and-fiftieth
anniversary
description: 1 coloured drawing (unframed; 210x195 mm; recto); penwork initials with pen-flourishes (verso)
language: French (Anglo-Norman). Added text on dorse: English and Latin; with 20th-century leather wrapping fastened at the top (older leather wrapping preserved)
littera textualis. Added text on dorse: littera cursiva

title: Prayer Book
provenance:
Probably made for Libertus Schaloun (Librecht van Hulsbergen), prior of the Abby of St. Trond. E. Denie, Antwerp (1941). Acquired in 1952 from antiquarian bookseller A.L. van Gendt, Eemnes (cat. 4, p. 38-39, nr. 129, fig.), as a present from the Friends of the
Library
description: 38 full-page miniatures (84/73x60/54 mm) with border decoration; 12 miniatures in the calendar (35/27x63/59 mm); 3 illustrations in the margin; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 17r, 22r, 31r, 37r, 55r, etc.)
Binding: 19th-century brown leather; gilt
annotation: Calendar of the Abby of St. Trond: feasts in red include St. Eucherius (20 February), St. Libertus (14 July), Translation of St. Trudo and St. Eucherius (11 August), St. Trudo (23 November)

title: Antiphonary (diurnal; winter part; incomplete)
provenance: Purchased in 1953 from antiquarian bookseller W. Salloch, New York (cat. 124, no. 1a)
description: 1 full-page drawing (unframed; 105x65 mm); 1 historiated penwork initial (42x39 mm); penwork initials with pen-flourishes (ff. 41v, 72r
Palimpsest: parts of decoration and penflourishes (f. 118r-v)
Binding: 18th(?)-century vellum
annotation: Quires are unbound and laying loose in binding. Incomplete: 16 leaves missing between ff. 49 and 54 and 16 leaves between ff. 71 and 72. Suffrages to St. Francis (f. 71#) and St. Clare (f. 71#)

title: Charters, privileges and other ducuments of the cities of Flanders concerning Flanders
provenance:
Ceded in 1766 by the Provinciale Raad van Vlaanderen (Provincial Council of Flanders) at Ghent. F. van Limborch; his sale in 1766 at J. Gaillard, The Hague (cat. 24 February, mss. in fol. p. 16 no. 367). Transfered in 1811 from the Ministerie van Oorlog (Ministry of
War), The Hague
description: 1 illustration in the margin; penwork initials with pen-flourishes (ff. 2r, 2v, 3r, 4r, 12v, etc.)
Binding: 16th-century brown leather; blind

title: New Testament with the Old Testament Epistle Readings
provenance:
J. Marcus, his sale in 1750 in Amsterdam (cat. p. 2 no. 10)); where purchased by Vonk. P.B. van Damme; his sale in 1764 at The Hague (cat. p. 184 no. 1269 in fol.). Enschedé family; their sale in 1867 at Amsterdam/The hague (cat. p. 23 no 223); where purchased by
antiquarian bookseller J.H. Dunk. A. Bogaers (d. 1870); presented in 1875 by his daughter together with the collection Bogaers
description: 2 historiated penwork initials, coarse (70x50 and 55x50 mm); penwork initials with pen-flourishes (ff. 3r, 22v, 31v, 51r, 103v)
Binding: 17th-/18th-century vellum; blind
annotation: Written for Hugo de Netelhorst, hence the possible place of origin

title: Gospel Book
provenance:
Made for Albert Beynop, brother of Ghysbert; later owned by Lambert Beynop `woennende in lewestien'. Bertam Hitfield, his sale in 1724 in Culemborg (cat. ms. no. B). Sold in 1731 at S. Schouten, Amsterdam (cat. 24 January, Folio no. 34). B. Huydecoper (d. 1778), his
sale in 1779 at P. Schouten, Amsterdam (cat. 29 March, p. 113 no. 4 in fol.); where purchased by J.A. Clignett (d. 1827), his sale in 1828 at B. Scheurleer, The Hague (cat. 28 April, p. 1 no. 11 in fol.); where purchased by N. Carbasius (d. 1834), his sale in 1835 at B. Scheurleer,
The Hague (cat. 13 April, p. 1 no. 6 in fol.); where purchased by B. Scheurleer. P.G.J. Hoog van ter Aar, his sale in 1863 at J. van Baalen & Zn, Rotterdam (cat. 30 November, p. 3 no. 26); where purchased by A. Bogaers (d. 1870); presented in 1870 by his daughter together with the
collection Bogaers
description: 1 coloured unframed drawing (240x190 mm); penwork initials with border decoration (ff. 35r, 42r, 58r, 95r); penwork initials with pen-flourishes (ff. 2r, 5r, 8v, etc.)
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt; by the `Hague medallion bindery'

title: Book of Hours
provenance: A. Bogaers (d. 1870); presented in 1870 by his daughter together with the collection of Bogaers
description: Decorated initials with or without border decoration (ff. 14r, 93r, 133r); penwork initials with pen-flourishes in 2 styles (ff. 65r, 158v, 181r (partly with painted eye) and ff. 66r, 159v, 197r, 206r, 231r)
Added (f. 64v): 1 miniature (117x76 mm)
Added (f. 196v): 1 miniature (100x61) with border decoration in Liège style
Binding: 16th-century brown leather (rebacked)
annotation:
Liège calendar: feasts in red include Dedication of the Church of Tongres (7 May), St. Lambertus (28 April, 17 September), St. Servaes (11 May), St. Giles (1 September), St. Maternus (25 September), St. Denis (9 October), St. Hubertus (3 November), St. Leonardus (6
November). Litany: St. Augustine first among the confessors. 1 mounted coloured woodcut (f. 205v) with printed border decoration (Entry of Christ in Jerusalem)

title: Eike von Repgow, Saksenspiegel
provenance: Purchased in 1848 at the sale of the collection of C. van Alkemade & P. van der Schelling at J. de Vries, A. Brondgeest and C.F. Roos, Amsterdam (cat. 17 January, no. 7)
description:
2 column miniatures (c. 65x47 mm) with decorated initial and border decoration; 1 illustration in the margin (coat of arms); 1 decorated initial with border decoration (f. 1r); all border decoration in Utrecht style (`tri-petals'); penwork initials with pen-flourishes
in Utrecht style (`early') throughout
Binding: 17th-/18th-century vellum; gilt

title: Thomas a Kempis, Dialogus noviciorum (Book I-IV). And other texts
provenance:
Made for the Monastery Gross-Frankenthal (near Worms). Canons Regular of the Monastery of St. John the baptist, Rebdorf; probably seized in 1800 by the French occupying forces. Hardy, Sens (19th cent.). Comte Daru, Paris (19th cent.). Purchased in 1861 from antiquarian
bookseller Tross, Paris
description: 1 historiated initial (40x32 mm); decorated initials (ff. 1r, 13r, 137v)
Binding: 20th-century brown leather conserving parts of the contemporary brown leather binding; blind made at Gross-Frankenthal
spatial: Gross Frankenthal (near Worms), Monastery of St. Mary Magdalene, Canons Regular

title: Psalter
provenance: Clemens Bylharbly (c. 1600). Acquired before 1880, way of acquisition unknown
description: 1 historiated initial (104x75 mm); 9 historiated initials (51/45x4 9/43 mm); decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 9r, 10v, 14v, 17r, 17v, etc.)
Binding: 15th-century brown leather; blind

title: Book of Hours (use of Cambrai; added section: Premonstrantensian use), containing in French: Suite de prières en vers pour la messe
provenance: Jenne Lengrant, widow of Jehan Magremon (16th century). Purchased in 1848 at a sale at H.C. Schetsberg, Leeuwarden (cat. 30 Nov.-2 Dec., no. 36)
description: 1 full-page miniature (80x50 mm); 1 historiated initial (27x33 mm) with border decoration; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 37r, 51v, 54r, 56v, 61r, etc.)
Added sections: decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 21r, 86r)
Binding: 18th-century vellum
annotation:
Arras calendar: feasts in red include Deposition of St. Vedastus (6 February), his Relation (15 July) and Translation (1 October). Litany: St. Vedastus first among the confessors. Leaves with decorated initials missing before ff. 46 and 53 (Hours of the Virgin: Prime
and Sext)

title: Missal (noted; use of Utrecht)
provenance: Parish church of Elden, Gelderland (15th century), later: Nederlands Hervormde Kerk; sold in 1882 to the Rijksarchief Gelderland, Arnhem; transferred in 1928
description:
2 historiated initials (100x105 and 95x100 mm); 1 historiated penwork initial (70x70 mm) with pen-flourishes; decorated initials with border decoration in Utrecht style (`thistles'; ff. 19r, 115v, 129v, 134r); penwork initials with pen-flourishes (ff. 24v, 31r, 84v,
140r, 142r, etc.)
Binding: 19th-century brown leather; blind (made after 1882)
annotation: Utrecht calendar (incomplete: January-February missing). Canonplate probably lost

bibliographicCitation: Oranje-Nassau Boekerij 1898, p. 11, no. 14, with 3 figs. (after p. 8 en before p. 11)
The Hague 1998, p. 18, colour fig. 15, p. 47 no. 15
Saurma-Jeltsch 2001, II, p. 26 no. 16, passim, figs. 144, 221

title: Rudolf von Ems, Willehalm von Orlens
creator: Diebold Lauber, workshop
provenance: Catharina of Austria, margravine of Baden (1420-1493; her daughter Cimborga of Baden (1450-1501); Breda Castle; Stadholder's library, The Hague; 1798 to Nationale Bibliotheek (now: Koninklijke Bibliotheek), The Hague
description: 39 coloured drawings, unframed (245/145x200x160 mm); 1 decorative opening page (f. 11r)
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt; made by the First Stadholder's bindery (active c. 1755-1760); with coat of arms of Stadholder William V
annotation: 8 leaves missing, some, or all, containing drawings

bibliographicCitation: The Hague 1983, no. 19, fig. on p. 53
title: Missal (use of Utrecht)
provenance: purchased in 1809 as no. 253 of the collection of Jacob Visser (1724-1804) of The Hague
description: Penwork initials with pen-flourishes in South-Holland style (`radishes'; ff. 1r, 8v, 67r, 102r, 135r, etc.) and different style (f. 107v)
Inserted: 1 full-page miniature (216x154 mm) with border decoration in Delft style (related to `kriezel')
Binding: contemporary brown leather; blind (rebacked)
annotation: No calendar

title: Jacob van Maerlant, Der Naturen Bloeme
provenance: purchased in 1809 as no. 168 of the collection of Jacob Visser (1724-1804) of The Hague
description: 465 column miniatures (70/16x73/60 mm); 1 historiated initial (22x33 mm); 34 schematic drawings; decorated initials with border decoration
Binding: 19th-century brown leather

provenance: Nicholas Heinsius (sold in 1682). Pieter van Damme (sold in 1764). C. van Buuren (sold in 1779). Puchased in 1784 by Jacob Visser (1724-1804) of The Hague; purchased in 1809 as no. 169 of the Visser collection
description: 6 historiated initials (23/86x30/80 mm) with border decoration; 1 illustration in the margin; decorated initials (ff. 54v, 55r, 55v); penwork initials with pen-flourishes (ff. 8r, 8v, 12v, etc)
Binding: 20th-century brown leather (199#) made by L. Gimbrère (18th-century vellum binding; gilt; still present)

title: Guillaume de Deguileville, Die pelgrimage van der menscheliker creaturen
provenance: M. R"ver; his sale in 1806 at Haak et socii, Leiden and P. den Hengst, Amsterdam (cat. 2 June, pt. II, no. 51). C.G. Hultman; purchased in 1821 at his sale at H. Palier et Fil., `s-Hertogenbosch (cat. 9 July, no. 4)
description: 1 two-column miniature (126x124 mm); 22 column miniatures (78/41x60/53 mm)
Binding: contemporary brown leather (rebacked)

bibliographicCitation: Van den Bergen-Pantens 1993, pp. 324, 352 no. XXXIX
title: Bible moralisée
provenance:
Antoine de Bourgogne, the Great Bastard (d. 1504, coat of arms, over erasure; emblem, motto; signature); by descent to his grandson Adolphe de Bourgogne (d. 1540; motto/signature). Joseph Désiré Lupus (d. 1822) of Brussels; purchased with his collection in 1819 by King
William I of The Netherlands; kept from 1819-1822 at the Musée Lupus in the Palace of Charles de Lorraine at Brussels (no. A 44) and transferred in 1823 to the KB
description: 1 two-column miniature (153x143 mm); 44 column miniatures (65x60/55 mm); decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 1r, 7v, 15v, 25v, 32r, etc.); penwork initials with pen-flourishes throughout
Added: illustrations in the margin (coat of arms, motto and emblem)
Binding: 18th-/19th-century brown velvet

bibliographicCitation: The Hague 1983, no. 36, colour pl. on cover
title: Breviary (Psalter and Common of Saints only; use of Autun)
creator: Master of the `Prélats Bourguignons', follower
provenance:
made for Jean Rolin, bishop of Autun (1408-1483). Joseph Désiré Lupus (d. 1822) of Brussels; purchased with his collection in 1819 by King William I of The Netherlands; kept from 1819-1822 at the Musée Lupus in the Palace of Charles de Lorraine at Brussels (no. A 15)
and transferred in 1823 to the KB
description: 8 historiated initials (45/35x55/45 mm); 38 illustrations in the margin (11 coats of arms of Jean Rolin); decorated initials with border decoration
Binding: 18th-century green leather; gilt

bibliographicCitation: Smeyers 1998, p. 319 nt. 54, fig. 44 on p. 320
title: Miroir de l'âme pécheresse. Translation from the Latin by Jean Miélot
provenance: Joseph Désiré Lupus (d. 1822) of Brussels; purchased with his collection in 1819 by King William I of The Netherlands; kept from 1819-1822 at the Musée Lupus in the Palace of Charles de Lorraine at Brussels (no. B 107) and transferred in 1823 to the KB
description: 1 pendrawing (162x115 mm); 7 large calligraphic initials (ff. 1r, 1v, 2v, 3r, 3v, 4r, 4v); decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 5r, 5v, 7v, 16r, 26r, etc.)
Binding: contemporary brown leather; blind (spine repaired)

title: Statutes, ordonnances and armorial of the Order of the Golden Fleece
provenance:
presented in 1473 by Gilles Gobet, King of Arms of the Order of the Golden Fleece, to Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy and the other Knights during the Chapter of the Order held at Valenciennes; kept in the Treasury of the Golden Fleece at Brussels; taken away by the
Treasurer Claude-François de Humyn (d. 1735) or his daughter  Claudine Charlotte de Corte; by descent to her daughter Marie-Livine de Corte (ownership inscription), wife of Philippe-Eugène de Poederlé; purchased in 1781 at the Poederlé sale by Georges-Joseph Gérard (1734-1814) of
Brussels; purchased in 1818 by the Dutch Government with the Gérard collection and placed in the Algemeen Rijksarchief (now: Nationaal Archief) at The Hague; transferred to the KB in 1832 (Gérard no. A 27)
description: (I) 1 full-page miniature (172x113 mm); 92 miniatures (185/155x120/105 mm); 1 historiated initial (70x80 mm; coat of arms); decorated initials with border decoration on nearly all text pages, all borders containing the emblems of the Order
Added section (II) (ff. 74r, 74v, 77v-80v): 9 miniatures (180/165x120/110 mm);
Added section (III) (ff. 84r-85v): 4 drawings (voortekeningen voor not-executed miniatures; 170x110 mm))
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt

title: Psalter with glosses of Anselm of Laon
provenance:
member of the Pierson family (S.M.I.?; 18th century). Joseph Désiré Lupus (d. 1822) of Brussels; purchased with his collection in 1819 by King William I of The Netherlands; kept from 1819-1822 at the Musée Lupus in the Palace of Charles de Lorraine at Brussels (no. A
1) and transferred in 1823 to the KB
description: 4 historiated initials (115/45x75/55 mm); 1 decorated page with 5 historiated roundels (200x145 mm); decorated initials (ff. 31v, 68v, 89r, 110v, 128r, etc.)
Binding: 18th-century black velvet over older brown leather; with clamps inscribed on inside: "S.M.I. Pierson PBR"

title: Statutes and ordonnances of the Order of the Golden Fleece
provenance: Possibly made for Count Engelbert II of Nassau; by descent to the Counts of Nassau and Princes of Orange-Nassau, the later Stadholders, at The Hague; carried off in 1795 to Paris by the French and restituted to the KB in 1816
description: 1 miniature (150x129 mm); 1 historiated initial with border decoration (f. 4r)
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt with coat of arms of Stadholder William V

title: Le séjour de deuil pour la mort de Philippe de Commines
provenance:
dedicated by the author to Hélène de Chambes, widow of Philippe de Commines (1447-1511). Anne de Bavière, Princesse Palatine at the Castle of Anet; purchased in 1724 at the sale of this library at P. Gandouin at Paris (15 Nov) by Cardinal G. Du Bois; sale of G. Du Bois
and J.P. Bignon in 1725 at J. Swart & P. de Hondt, The Hague (cat. 27 Aug., pt. 1, p. 545 no. 5418). J.H. van Wassenaer-van Obdam; his sale in 1750 at P. de Hondt, The Hague (cat. 10 Aug., p. 62 no. 793). Purchased in 1816 at the sale of the collection of J.Th. Royer of The Hague (d.
1807; signature with motto `Constanter') at B. Scheurleer & A. Bakhuyzen, The Hague (cat. 1-6 Apr., p. 63 no. 785) by the KB
description: 17 miniatures (125/105x110 mm); decorated initials (ff. 2r, 3v, 4v, 5r, 6r, etc.)
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt on spine

title: Jacob van Maerlant, Rijmbijbel. Idem, Die wrake van Jherusalem
provenance: Purchased in 1809 as no. 91 of the collection of Jacob Visser (1724-1804) of The Hague
description: 3 historiated initials (...x... mm) with border decoration; 1 illustration in the margin; penwork initials with pen-flourishes throughout
Binding: 15th(?)-century brown leather; blind (spine repaired)

title: Gospels
provenance: Georges-Joseph Gérard (1734-1814) of Brussels; purchased in 1818 by the Dutch Government with the Gérard collection and placed in the Algemeen Rijksarchief (now: Nationaal Archief) at The Hague; transferred to the KB in 1832
description: 4 full-page miniatures (215x154, 218x160, 234x150, 220x160 mm), 10 pages with canontables, decorated initials
Binding: 18th-century brown leather

provenance: Joseph Désiré Lupus (d. 1822) of Brussels; purchased with his collection in 1819 by King William I of The Netherlands; kept from 1819-1822 at the Musée Lupus in the Palace of Charles de Lorraine at Brussels (no. A 43) and transferred in 1823 to the KB

description: 1 two-column miniature (178x153 mm); 1 illustration in the margin; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 1r, 88v; 3v, 4r, 5r, etc.)

title: Le Livre de l'information des princes. Translation from the Latin by Jean Golein
creator: Master of Étienne Sanderat de Bourgogne
provenance:
made in 1453 for Giovanni Arnolfini (d. 1470), Luccese merchant at Bruges and Rouen (colophon). Philip of Cleves (d. 1528; coat of arms, over erasure); purchased in 1531 from his estate by Henri III, Count of Nassau (d. 1538); by descent to the Princes of Orange-
Nassau, the later Stadholders, at The Hague; sold in 1749 at the sale of the Orange-Nassau library at P. van Cleef & D. Monnier, The Hague (cat. 1 Dec., p. 218, no. 69), where purchased by J.A. Nuske; sold in 1757 at the Nuske sale at O. van Thol & N. van Daalen, The Hague (cat. 14

Added: 1 illustration in the margin (coat of arms)
Binding: 18th-century brown leather; gilt; with coat of arms of Stadholder William V

creator: Franco-Saxon school
provenance:
Presented c. 975 by Dirk II, Count of Holland, and his wife Hildegard to Egmond Abbey; still mentioned in the inventory of 1571; transferred to Haarlem, and afterwards to Cologne and in the 17th century to Utrecht; purchased in 1830 from the Oud-Bisschoppelijke
Clerezij, Utrecht

Binding: 20th-century binding made by L. Gimbrere (199#)
annotation:
2 dedication miniatures were added c. 975 to commemorate the donation of the book by Dirk II. The binding covered with gold and precious stones, which Dirk II had made also, was lost between 1571-1574 and replaced with a leather binding  from 1574. This binding was
removed in the KB after 1830; rebound in 1949 and 199#

provenance:
Bridgettinesses of the Monastery Marienwater at Den Bosch (16th century). D.-C. en J.-J. van Voorst; their sale in 1860 at F. Muller, Amsterdam (cat. mss. no. 139). Willem Hekking 1887. Purchased in 1897 from antiquarian bookseller J. Schulman at Amersfoort (cat. no.
292)
description: 1 historiated initial (60x55 mm) with border decoration (strewn border; decorated initials (ff. 22v, 38v, 54v, 68r, 81r, 97r, etc.)
Binding: 18th-century red velvet
language: I: Latin; II: Latin and Dutch
annotation: f. 143r: `sancte Lambertus onsen pateron'

title: Book of Hours (use of Rome)
provenance: Purchased in 1897 from antiquarian bookseller Champion, Paris
description:
3 full-page miniatures (89x46 mm) with border decoration); 15 miniatures (89/59x48/46 mm) with decorated initial and border decoration; 8 historiated initials (22/15x21x11 mm) with border decoration; 4 illustrations in the margin; decorated initials with border

Binding: 19th-century brown leather; blind; with silver heraldic shield with initials A D

title: Book of Hours (Dominican use)
creator: Moerdrecht Master, follower
provenance: Agatha Francisci van Leyden (= sister Aechte Frans Backersdr., Jacobines at Leyden; 16th century). Purchased in 1897 from antiquarian bookseller J. Halle, Munich
description: Penwork initials with pen-flourishes in South Holland(?) style (ff. 17r, 48r, 65r, 106r, 122r, etc.)
Added: 8 full-page miniatures (92/54x58/33 mm) with border decoration in Utrecht style (`multi-coloured leaves')
Binding: 16th-century brown leather; blind
annotation:
Dominican calendar: feasts in red include St. Thomas of Aquino (7 March) and his Translation (28 January), the Translation of St. Peter Martyr (7 May), St. Dominic `patris ordinis nostri' (5 August) and his Translation (23 May). Full-page miniatures missing before f.
92 (Short Hours of the Cross), f. 97 (Hours of the Holy Spirit).

title: Book of Hours in Dutch
provenance: Purchased in 1897
description: Decorated initials with border decoration in IJssel region style (`Sarijs'-group; ff. 83r, 108,
Added: 4 miniatures (c. 80x57 mm) with border decoration in Utrecht style (coarse `thistles' and `teardrops')
Binding: 19th-century brown leather; blind
annotation:
No calendar. Opening pages with decorated initials, and probably full-page miniatures, missing before f. 1 (Hours of the Virgin), f. 38 (Long Hours of the Cross), f. 65 (Hours of the Holy Spirit), f. 133 (Office of the Dead). Possibly also miniatures missing at Lauds,
Prime, Terce, Sext and None of the Long Hours of the Cross

purchased in 1897

2 historiated initials (55x55/50 mm) with border decoration; 1 decorated initial with border decoration (f. 130r); decorated initials with pen-flourishes in a style related to Arnhem (ff. 35r, 146v); penwork initials with pen-flourishes in a style related to Arnhem
(ff. 12r, 18r, 29r, 53v, 58r, etc.)
Binding: 17th-/18th-century brown leather; blind

Huis met de Hoofden, Amsterdam (cat. 29 April, pt. 1, no. 181), where purchased by Groebe. Sold in 1938 at a sale at Van Stockum, The Hague (cat. 28 Nov.-3 Dec., no. 1811), where bought by antiquarian bookseller Meyer Elte, The Hague; purchased in 1938 from Meyer Elte

bibliographicCitation: Brayer & Korteweg 2003, microfiche pp. 1353-1356, guide p. 41-42
title: Donato Acciuolo, Vie de Scipion l'Africain.
Plutarch, Vie de Pompée.
Leonardo Bruni Aretino, Vie de Cicero (Cicero Novus). Translations from the Latin by Simon de Bourgouin
provenance:
presented by Simon de Bourgouin to King Louis XII of France (d. 1515; signature). Guy de Baudreuil, abbot of St. Martin du Bois (1521; ownership inscription). Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Prés, Paris (cat. of c. 1740, no. 1431); probably lost after the dissolution of the
abbey in 1791. Purchased in Paris by Peter Dubrowski; sold in 1805 to Czar Alexander I of Russia and placed in the Imperial Library at St. Petersburg (shelfmark Fr.F.V.IV.4); sold abroad by the Russian government in the 1920s. Purchased by Fritz Mannheimer of Amsterdam (d. 1939);
confiscated during World War II by the German occupying forces and restituted after 1945; since 1953 on permanent loan from the Instituut Collectie Nederland (ICN), Amsterdam (formerly: Dienst voor 's-Rijks Verspreide Kunstvoorwerpen, The Hague, and Rijksdienst voor Beeldende Kunst,
The Hague)
description: 34 full-page miniatures (262/223x147/124 mm); 29 full-page miniatures including some lines of text (268/152x140/124 mm); decorated initials (ff. 2r, 7v, 15r, 17r, 19v, etc.)
Binding: 16th-century brown leather; gilt (Grolier-type)

5 full-page miniatures (111/107x65/61 mm) with border decoration; 27 miniatures (42/32x35/29 mm) with border decoration; 1 historiated initial (26x26 mm) with border decoration; decorated initials with border decoration (ff. 8r, 17r, 65r, 95r, 134r, etc.); all border
decoration in Ghent-Bruges style (`strewn borders')

annotation: General calendar: feasts in red include St. Nichasius (14 December). Added miniature lost before fol. 53 (Hours of the Virgin: Vespers). Traces of pilgrims badges on ff. 1r, 6v, 181v

Calendar of Augustine Order: feasts in red include St. George (24 April), St. Augustine (28 August), the 11,000 Virgins (21 October), St. Barbara (4 December), St. Nichasius (14 December), feasts in black St. Monica (4 May), Translation of St. Augustine (11 October).
Litany: St. Augustine first among the confessors. Penwork similar to The Hague, KB, 129 E 21

title: Prayer Book
provenance: Th. Sonner (19th cent.). A. Labitte, Paris (c. 1895). Albert Hyma, Ann Arbor, Mich. (1919); acquired from Hyma by H. Bos Kzn. and presented in 1957 to the KB

annotation:
Liège calendar: feasts in red include: St. Servatius (13 May), his translation (7 June) and Dedication of the Church of St. Servatius (9 September), St. Francis `onse vader` (4 October), St. Denis (9 October), St. Hubert (3 November, St. Leonard (6 November). F. 15r:
Circle with dates 1500-1519
